description: Smallest base relative to which n is palindromic.
comments: From _Hieronymus Fischer_, Jan 05 2014: (Start)The terms are well defined since each number m > 2 is palindromic in base m - 1.A number n>6 is prime, if a(n) = n-1.Numbers m of the form m = q*p with q < p - 1, are palindromic in base p-1, and therefore a(m) <= p.Numbers m of the form m := j*(p^k - 1)/(p - 1), 1<=j
links: Vincenzo Librandi and Hieronymus Fischer, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 from Vincenzo Librandi).
K. S. Brown, On General Palindromic Numbers
example: n = 4 = 11_3 is palindromic in base 3, but not palindromic in base 2, hence a(4) = 3.n = 14 = 22_6 is palindromic in base 6, but not palindromic in any other base < 6, hence a(14) = 6.
mathematica: palQ[n_, k_] := Reverse[x = IntegerDigits[n, k]] == x; Table[k = 2; While[! palQ[n, k], k++]; k, {n, 92}] (* _Jayanta Basu_, Jul 26 2013 *)
